Award.AwardTitle: EDU: A Capture-the-Flag Service for Computer Security Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Security games such as Capture-the-Flag (CTF) competitions tap into and cultivate the intrinsic motivation in people to solve puzzles. Such games provide a compelling experience for security practitioners looking to test their skills. Given the level of engagement these games produce, there have been efforts to bring the format into the classroom. While CTFs are ideal for measuring the level of expertise of its participants, there are significant issues that must be overcome before the format can be used in the classroom. Specifically, CTF challenges are often targeted towards experts, consist of static problems with static solutions, are difficult to customize, and require significant time and resources to deploy.

We are currently addressing these issues by building open CTF software and services to support scaffolded, metamorphic challenges in a manner that is easily configured and deployed by instructors across the country to teach their courses. Specifically, the content and difficulty of our CTFs are carefully scaffolded in order to quickly develop confidence and competence in students rather than boredom or frustration. Challenges are generated metamorphically so that each student receives a unique set of challenges in order to deter cheating and to better ensure that every student learns the material. The CTFs are configurable to allow instructors to add and remove challenges based on the topics they wish to cover in their courses. Finally, the CTFs are freely available to instructors in a variety of formats that can be deployed readily.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have created and released a set of CTFs that can be used by anyone to learn about and practice skills in security.   This work has shown the efficacy of our approach for building scaffolded, polymorphic CTFs that are easy to deploy and highly extensible.  There were no other equivalents prior to them and the evaluation results from student surveys show that they were very effective.  All of CTFs are publicly available and can be played by anyone. 

The CTFs target all levels of expertise:

The first targets high-school students and features a set of exercises that are woven in to a popular Young-Adult series Divergent.   A screenshot of the site is included and can be played at https://crypto.cyberpdx.org

The second targets undergraduate students and features a set of exercises that are aligned with the popular Bryant & O'Halloran textbook "Computer Systems Programming".  A screenshot of the site is included and can be played at https://cs201.oregonctf.org

The third targets advanced undergraduate students and features a set of exercises that are aligned with Sikorski and Honig's "Practical Malware Analysis".  A screenshot of the site is included and can be played at https://malware.oregonctf.org

Publications from the project are included below:

Wu-chang Feng, Robert Liebman, Lois Delcambre, Michael Lupro, Tim Sheard, Scott Britell, Gerald Recktenwald "CyberPDX: A Camp for Broadening Participation in Cybersecurity", USENIX Advances in Security Education (ASE), August 2016. https://thefengs.com/wuchang/papers/feng17cyberpdx.pdf


Wu-chang Feng, "A Divergent-themed CTF and Urban Race for Introducing Security and Cryptography", USENIX Advances in Security Education (ASE), August 2016. https://thefengs.com/wuchang/papers/feng16divergent.pdf

Wu-chang Feng, "A Scaffolded, Metamorphic CTF for Reverse Engineering", USENIX Summit on Gaming, Games, and Gamification in Security Education (3GSE), August 2015. https://thefengs.com/wuchang/papers/3gse15metactf.pdf
